At that time, Bodhisattva King Prasenajit asked the Buddha, World-Honored One! If there are dharmas,
can there be seen dharmas?
If there are seen dharmas, can one see the TathÄgata?
The Buddha said:
There are.
Why is it so?
King Prasenajit!
The characteristics of form are unborn, the intrinsic nature is unborn, seeing form in this way is seeing the TathÄgata;
in this way, the characteristics of feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are all unborn, the intrinsic nature is unborn, seeing consciousness in this way is seeing the TathÄgata.

The equality of samÄdhi is pure seeing; in this way, I attained pure seeing from Buddha DÄ«paá¹ƒkara.

World-Honored One!
The TathÄgata who came to light the lamp, how was he seen?

VegadhÄrin!

If a bodhisattva wishes to see the Buddha in this way, he should see DÄ«paá¹ƒkara TathÄgata as I see him, through one Dharma.

just as the body of DÄ«paá¹ƒkara is, my body is also the same.
One body, one dharma, realizing the non-duality of dharmas, not discriminating realization is the wisdom of causes and conditions.
If one sees causes and conditions, then one sees the Dharma;
By seeing the Dharma, one sees the TathÄgata.
If one realizes cessation in all places where the mind arises, not entering nirvÄá¹‡a, not attaining the expedient wisdom of birth and death, this is the display.
What is that wisdom of true reality?
What is it for the Å›rÄvakas?
When it is real, then one touches liberation.
In this way, when it is real, the bodhisattva also attains non-touching liberation, this is the display;
What is it for the pratyekabuddhas?
When it is real, then one touches liberation.
In this way, when it is real, the bodhisattva also attains non-touching liberation, this is the display.
The wisdom of true reality means knowing that suffering is neither true nor real.
What is wisdom?
It is called non-real wisdom, because it arises from endless inversion.
Knowing suffering does not arise, ultimately not arising, if one knows suffering in this way as not arising, this is called the knowledge of suffering.
How does one cut off the arising of suffering?
As with the way of the arising of suffering, one cuts off the arising of suffering in this way.
What is called the arising of suffering?
Because of arising, it is called arising, equally cutting off the arising of suffering.
If future arising is cut off in the future, this Dharma is so by nature, there is no Dharma that arises or is cut off.
The arising of suffering is caused by craving, cutting off that craving is called cutting off craving.
What is the cessation of suffering?
If the nature of the arising of suffering is ultimately extinguished, no Dharma is lost in cessation, therefore it is called cessation.
If one extinguishes all characteristics of clinging, the meaning is not appropriate. What Dharma arises?
What Dharma ceases?
What is the path?

That is to say, there is a path - whether wholesome, unwholesome, contaminated, uncontaminated, defiled, undefiled, conditioned, or unconditioned - that cannot be attained, and this is called the path.
Equality is called the path, because all dharmas are true;ğŸ”½Tranquility is called the path, because all afflictions are completely abandoned;
Peace is called the path, because one does not depart from all skillful means;
Non-outflow is called the path, because all outflows are exhausted;
Non-practice is called the path, because those with discriminating views cannot practice it;
Easy practice is called the path, because it can be practiced by those who practice correctly;
Non-abandonment is called the path, because it is not abandoned by past TathÄgatas;
The characteristic of separation is called the path, because it can eliminate all doubts.
If one does not enter duality in this path, this is called the path;
If one understands the meaning of these four truths, it is called the knowledge of true reality.
If one does not give rise to aspirations for the vehicles of the hearers and solitary realizers with regard to these four truths, then one can be said to have the supernormal knowledge of wisdom.
Moreover, King of Fierce Energy!
One who has the supernormal knowledge of wisdom knows the vehicle of the hearers, but does not grasp or dwell in it;
knows the vehicle of the solitary realizers, but does not grasp or dwell in it - this is the supernormal knowledge of wisdom.
Moreover, King of Fierce Energy!

One who has the supernormal knowledge of wisdom, with a single mind knows the minds of all beings, and with the essence of a single mind knows the essence of the minds of all beings. Whether it is the mind or wisdom, the two minds do not arise - this is the supernormal knowledge of wisdom.
Moreover, King of Fierce Energy!ğŸ”½One who has the supernormal knowledge of wisdom knows and sees the past without obstruction or hindrance, yet the mind does not arise with regard to the past;
knows and sees the future without obstruction or hindrance, and the mind does not arise with regard to the future or the past;
Knowing the unobstructed and unimpeded present, yet not engaging in conceptual proliferation regarding the past, future, and present mind, is the supernormal power of wisdom.
Moreover, King of Fierce Energy!

The supernormal power of wisdom is to know the exhaustion of wisdom yet not exhaust the practice of wholesome roots, and to know the wisdom of non-arising while also knowing the accumulation [of causes]. This is the supernormal power of wisdom.
Moreover, King of Fierce Energy!

The supernormal power of wisdom is to know that all phenomena are ultimately quiescent and extinguished, to know that all phenomena are not caused by other conditions, and to not grasp nirvana due to the power of wisdom - in order to bring sentient beings to maturity. This is the supernormal power of wisdom of the bodhisattva.
Thus, King of Fierce Energy!
If a bodhisattva wishes to manifest this supernormal power of wisdom, they should skillfully accomplish the activities of wisdom and not engage in the activities of arrogance.
What are the activities of arrogance?

All intentional actions are the karma of pride, all actions with consciousness are the karma of pride, all mental actions are the karma of pride, all good actions done with pleasure, all views and giving that fall into [the realm of] form are the karma of pride, all precepts that fall into conceptualization are the karma of pride, all patience practiced based on self and others is the karma of pride, all mental discriminations and efforts are the karma of pride;
all discriminations of the body and prajÃ±Ä are also the karma of pride.
All who give rise to the conceit of self are the karma of pride:
'I am a bodhisattva.'
This is the karma of pride;
'I, a bodhisattva, abide.'
This is the karma of pride;
'I can continuously uphold the lineage of the Buddha, the lineage of the Dharma, and the lineage of the Saá¹…gha.'
This is the karma of pride;
'I benefit sentient beings.'
This is the karma of pride;

'The sentient beings who have not yet crossed over, I will cause them to cross over; those who have not yet been liberated, I will cause them to be liberated; those who have not yet been comforted, I can comfort them; those who have not yet attained nirvana, I will cause them to attain nirvana.'
This is the karma of arrogance;
'I practice giving, I uphold precepts, I am patient, I practice diligence, I meditate, I have wisdom.'
This is the karma of arrogance;
'I practice the mind of loving-kindness, I practice the mind of compassion, I practice the mind of joy, I practice the mind of equanimity.'
This is the karma of arrogance;
'I practice few desires, I practice contentment, I practice seclusion, I practice non-attachment.'
This is the karma of arrogance;
'I practice the dhÅ«ta practices, the practices of emptiness and stillness, the recollection and discernment.'
This is the karma of arrogance;
'I practice the practice of emptiness, I practice the signless, I practice the wishless.'
This is the karma of arrogance;
'I can speak truthfully, I can speak sincerely, I practice as I speak and recollect and discern.'
This is the work of conceit;
'I transcend the work of MÄra, transcend the four MÄra-snares, cut off all views, and practice patience.'

Recollecting and discerning this mental work, all such things are briefly explained here, 'I will attain enlightenment, turn the wheel of Dharma, enable sentient beings to attain liberation, and then enter nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder.'
Recollecting and discerning this mental work, King of Effort!
All mental activities and thoughts and speech are the work of conceit.
King of Effort!
What is the work of wisdom?
In such places, the mind, thought, and cognition do not arise, that is the work of wisdom;ğŸ”½The bodhisattva always performs the work of wisdom in this way.
How does the bodhisattva always perform the work of wisdom?
Namely, bodhisattvas always perform two kinds of activities. The second is to mature sentient beings and embrace the true Dharma.
How do bodhisattvas mature sentient beings?
It means to know through one's own wisdom the maturation of sentient beings.
Knowing through one's own wisdom means to abide in freedom from arrogance. Knowing in this way, one abides in freedom from attachment, not mind, not consciousness;
In this way, bodhisattvas are not mind, not consciousness. Bodhisattvas in this way mature sentient beings.
How do bodhisattvas embrace the true Dharma?
If bodhisattvas do not embrace all dharmas, this is the bodhisattvas' embracing of the true Dharma.
Not embracing form is embracing the true Dharma;
In this way, not embracing feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness is embracing the true Dharma.
In this sequence, not embracing the elements is embracing the true Dharma;
Not embracing the sense bases is embracing the true Dharma;
Not subsumed by wholesome dharmas or unwholesome dharmas is subsuming the true Dharma;
Not pure or impure, not contaminated or uncontaminated, conditioned or unconditioned, not worldly dharmas or supramundane dharmas, not subsuming in this way is subsuming the true Dharma;
Not subsuming in the characteristics of giving is subsuming the true Dharma, not subsuming in morality, patience, vigor, or meditation is subsuming the true Dharma.
Why is it so?
All that arises from conditions has characteristics of arising, it is not the Dharma, not the Vinaya, not subsuming the true Dharma.
Why is it so?
The characteristics of the TathÄgata's right enlightenment, which are without characteristics and unobstructed, cannot be grasped through characteristics or conditions.
If a bodhisattva knows such actions, that is called wisdom;
If with that wisdom one does what wisdom does, that is not exhaustive wisdom.
King of Effort,
What is the effort of wisdom?
It is analyzing the parts of the Dharma with phrases to attain the four unobstructed [abilities].
What are the four?

First, the unobstructed understanding of meaning, second, the unobstructed understanding of dharmas, third, the unobstructed understanding of language, and fourth, the unobstructed understanding of eloquence.

As for the unobstructed understanding of meaning, regarding all words, one only grasps the meaning and does not grasp the words - what is meant by meaning is correctly understanding the meaning of all dharmas.
Moreover, meaning refers to the inexpressible meaning. Knowing all the various words without forgetting the past and future sounds is called meaning.
Not grasping language, one attains accord with meaning. If one can be equal in this way regarding language and meaning, then one accords with meaning.
If one knows in this way, it is called the unobstructed understanding of meaning;
because one is unobstructed regarding all meanings, it is called the unobstructed understanding of meaning.
As for the unobstructed understanding of dharmas, it means following dharmas and not following non-dharmas.
Following dharmas is not thinking of non-dharmas.
Why is it so?
Because one's knowledge of all dharmas is apart from names and words.

As for the unobstructed understanding of dharmas, whether it is the vehicle or the Dharma, it is not different from the Dharma. In the characteristics of the Dharma realm, the Dharma realm is not destroyed.
Why is this?
The Dharma realm has one characteristic, which is called no characteristics.
In what is spoken, what is the Dharma language?

Having heard that language, it is equal to an echo. In accordance with faith and understanding, one believes in the spoken Dharma language, and the Dharma realm is equal. Understanding it through worldly conventions, one does not grasp at it. For these meanings, it is called the unobstructed understanding of dharmas.

All of this one knows as it is, according to the words and languages of the Dharma.

If one uses words and languages to cause other sentient beings to understand according to their own minds, one speaks in this way. One's own words and the words of others are not obstructed by each other, nor are they grasped or attached to.
Why is this?
Because one knows that all dharmas are without words and languages.
One thinks like this:
'What are words and languages?
If one speaks of any dharmas?
Such dharmas are not in the letters and words, and therefore cannot be obtained or spoken.
Moreover, those letters and words are not in the dharmas, and therefore cannot be obtained or spoken.
If one speaks letters and words, the letters and words have no sound;
If there were truly such words - good words and bad words - then they could not be obtained, and one should know that these words are not in the dharmas.
Those without obstruction in speech are unobstructed in all dharmas, and all dharmas do not function.
Why is it so?
Because dharmas do not function, all dharmas ultimately do not function.
Having known this, one explains it to others and teaches others to know it, which is called the unobstructed speech.
What is called the unobstructed eloquence?
If all speech is joyfully spoken, all sounds are joyfully spoken, and all names are joyfully spoken.
What is joyful speaking?
He speaks joyfully about meaning, about the Dharma, about truth, and about reality.
If there are sentient beings who understand and believe in the sounds and voices of the sÅ«tras, for those sentient beings he speaks joyfully about the sounds and voices of the sÅ«tras;

Those unimpeded eloquence in meaning, unimpeded eloquence in Dharma, unimpeded eloquence in words, and unimpeded eloquence in delight, all of these are rooted in wisdom, rely on wisdom to abide, and follow wisdom to practice. What is the root of listening?ğŸ”½What does listening rely on to abide?

Stirred-up King!

Moreover, King of Effort!
What is the root of that good and virtuous friend?
On what does he rely to abide?
What practice does he follow?
King of Effort!
That good and virtuous friend has reverence as his root, relies on reverence to abide, and follows reverence in practice.
Moreover, King of Effort!
What is the root of such reverence?
On what does it rely to abide?
What practice does it follow?
King of Effort!
Such reverence has a sincere mind as its root, relies on the sincere mind to abide, and follows the sincere mind in practice.
Moreover, King of Effort!
What is the root of such a sincere mind?
On what does it rely to abide?
What practice does it follow?
King of Effort!
Such a sincere mind has no deceit as its root, relies on no deceit to abide, and follows no deceit in practice.
Moreover, King of Effort,
what is the root of such non-deception?
on what does it depend?
what practices does it follow?
King of Effort!
such non-deception has great compassion as its root, it depends on great compassion, and it practices according to great compassion.
Moreover, King of Effort!
what is the root of such great compassion?
on what does it depend?
what practices does it follow?
King of Effort!
all sentient beings are the root of great compassion, it depends on all sentient beings, and it practices according to all sentient beings.
Why is it so?
King of Effort!
because bodhisattvas arouse the mind of great compassion and omniscience in order to liberate all sentient beings.
King of Effort!
this energetic wisdom, once a bodhisattva has aroused this one Dharma door, whether for one eon or the remainder of eons, speaking of different Dharmas is unobstructed.
They can make sentient beings not see their bodies but still hear the Dharma being taught, just as they wish.
They can make the Dharma sound come out from every pore of their own bodies, just as they wish.

They teach the Dharma in accordance with the profound practices of sentient beings, with eloquence and joy in speaking. They teach the Dharma by manifesting the bodily form of sentient beings, and others who come to argue cannot defeat them.

The bodhisattvas with wisdom can demonstrate all these dharmas to others, and thus understand everything.
Thus, the bodhisattvas know well the spells and poisons, know the locations of the spells and poisons, and know the various treatises;

King of Effort,
The bodhisattvas have this kind of wisdom effort. They sit and speak with millions of BrahmÄs, and they see each other, show each other their forms, and show each other their words.

In the same way, the blue and other colors of the bodhisattva's majestic light surpass those of the Brahmas. He has no longing for those Brahma abodes, and the Brahmas who come to the bodhisattva's place give rise to reverence.

In this way, he manifests mastery in all the celestial palaces, but the bodhisattva has no longing for them, no craving or delight, and gives rise to the thought of impermanence and the thought of suffering and non-self.
In this way, the bodhisattva accords with the liberation of all beings. Fenzhunwang!
This is the manifestation of wisdom.
Fenzhunwang!

Moreover, the bodhisattva, through the manifestation of wisdom, transforms a palace in the realm of Mara, surpassing the palace of Mara by a hundred thousand times, causing those Maras to long for and crave the superior palace;
having given rise to craving, their minds become free from arrogance;
having become free from arrogance, he causes them to abide in unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment, and then expounds the Dharma of impermanence for them.
Fenzhunwang!
This is how Bodhisattva Wisdom should understand the practice in all places.
Because of this wisdom, whether giving, receiving, or making vows, all should be understood in this way;

Because of this wisdom, whether oneself guarding morality, causing others to uphold morality, and with this morality vowing to attain enlightenment, one should understand in this way;ğŸ”½Because of this wisdom, whether oneself cultivating patience, causing others to cultivate patience, and with this cultivation of patience vowing to attain enlightenment, one should understand in this way;

A wise bodhisattva, by the power of wisdom, is able to fully attain all wholesome powers;
a wise bodhisattva, because of the mastery of wisdom, attains all wealth;
a wise bodhisattva, because of the leaping of wisdom, attains the supreme leaping in all dharmas;
a wise bodhisattva, because of grasping the power of wisdom, attains the adornment of the Buddha's likeness;
a wise bodhisattva, in all dharmas, practices in accordance with the principle without effort.
King of Leaping,
it is like a person in the world shooting an arrow upward, exerting its power naturally downward, until it reaches the ground without effort.
King of Leaping,

a wise bodhisattva is also like this. With the power of wisdom, he is able to shoot the arrow of vows without effort, naturally like this, falling into the ground of all wholesome dharmas, namely the ground of the site of enlightenment, manifesting the power of wisdom.

By the power of wisdom, he can move with his right hand the worlds equal to the sands of the Ganges River;
By the power of wisdom, he surpasses the retinue of Mara, surpasses the adornments of Mara, and attains the ten powers of the Tathagata that are included in enlightenment.

They cannot be surpassed by others, namely, they cannot be destroyed by all the worlds of gods, humans, and asuras.
King of Effort,
This is the effort of wisdom through the spiritual penetrations of precepts.
King of Effort,
Such effort of wisdom through the spiritual penetrations of precepts is not heard by beings who have not planted good roots.
King of Effort,
If a person, having heard this Dharma door, rejoices in his heart, such a person will be able to make effort through this effort.

In the sky, hundreds of thousands of devas, having seen this, all spoke with the same voice, saying:

If there are those who have faith and understanding in this kind of manifestation, and after having faith and understanding are able to give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, such people will adorn themselves with the adornments of the buddhas.
Why is this?
Because all these manifestations are in accordance with the mind of omniscience.
Moreover, World-Honored One!
If there are those who have not yet given rise to the mind of enlightenment, where will they be able to hear such inconceivable manifestation Dharma doors?
At that time, the World-Honored One praised the celestial sons in the sky, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
After praising them, he told the great bodhisattva King of Manifestations:
King of Manifestations!
I recall that in the past, after the TathÄgata DÄ«paá¹ƒkara, there was a seventh TathÄgata named VimalaprabhÄsa-rÄja (Pure Light King).
When that Buddha, the TathÄgata, extensively expounded this kind of heroic method, there was a bodhisattva named SamantaprabhÄsa who asked that TathÄgata about this method.
After the TathÄgata had expounded this method, eight thousand beings attained this kind of heroism and also attained the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas;
thirty-two thousand beings in the assembly all gave rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
At that time, I attained this kind of heroism, and subsequently, under the Buddha DÄ«paá¹ƒkara, I perfected enlightenment.
Thus it is, King of Heroic Stance!

After my nirvÄá¹‡a, if there are those who can listen to this method, those people will definitely quickly attain the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas, having taken up the mind of enlightenment.
When this heroic method was expounded, thirty-two thousand beings in the assembly, devas and humans, all gave rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.

Those devas rained down various flowers and hundreds of thousands of heavenly musical instruments to make offerings to the TathÄgata. By the Buddha's power, from those musical sounds came forth these wondrous words:

If there are sentient beings with a superior mind of faith and understanding, sharp faculties, faith and understanding in the Buddha's teachings, accomplishment in the practice of wisdom, embraced by good and virtuous friends, having planted good roots in the past, and with great compassion for all sentient beings, only then can they hear such a Dharma teaching;
having heard it, they will believe and understand, uphold it, and recite it.
At that time, Bodhisattva King of Effort asked the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

do bodhisattvas have these ten powers?

Do bodhisattvas have these eighteen distinctive qualities?
The Buddha said:
They all have them.
King of Effort!

All bodhisattvas, having accomplished their work in the eighth ground, attain the ninth ground, namely, they are endowed with eloquence, attain irreversible forbearance, and gather skillful means and the perfection of wisdom.
King of Effort!
The bodhisattva thus endowed with the ten powers and four fearlessnesses, having accomplished the eighteen distinctive qualities of the Buddha, attains the ninth ground.
King of Effort!
What are the ten bodhisattva powers of the bodhisattva?
First, the power of arousing the mind of omniscience, of a firm and profound mind, of great compassion being fulfilled, and of not abandoning any sentient beings;
Second, the power of not seeking any wealth, offerings, or fame, and of not craving or delighting in any rare things in the world;
Third, the power of fulfilling the mind of great compassion, of pure faith and understanding in all Buddha-dharmas, and of the ultimate truth of dharmas;
Fourth, the power of diligently applying oneself without laziness, of superior zeal, and of not being apart from mindfulness and dignified conduct;

Fifth, the power of the samÄdhi of unshakable abiding, far removed from the two extremes and in accord with the Dharma of causes and conditions, with the power of the complete quiescence of all views and practices;
Sixth, the power of fulfilling the perfection of wisdom, because the bodhisattva has completely extinguished all conceptualization, non-conceptualization, and the net of doubts and disputes;

Seventh, the power of not being weary in the cycle of birth and death, maturing all sentient beings, not being content with the incomplete [attainment of] worldly good roots, taking up worldly birth and death as if it were a dream, and not being weary in the cycle of birth and death;

Eighth, the power of the acceptance that all dharmas are unborn, the bodhisattva observing the nature of dharmas as originally devoid of sentient beings, originally devoid of essence, devoid of life, and devoid of pudgala, and having faith and understanding that all dharmas are unborn and unarising, able to have faith and understanding that the Dharma of the wheel is unborn, and having the acceptance that all dharmas of the wheel are unborn;

Ninth, the power of the liberation gate of entering emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, and the liberation gate of the knowledge and vision of liberation in the vehicle of the hearers and the vehicle of the solitary buddhas;
Tenth, bodhisattvas are able to know for themselves the profound Dharma, and observe the mental activities of all sentient beings, knowing the unobstructed power of fulfillment.
Stirred-up King!
These are the ten bodhisattva powers of the bodhisattvas.
Stirred-up King!
What are the four fearlessnesses of the bodhisattvas?
First, bodhisattvas uphold all that they hear, attain dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s, and do not forget what they have learned. They are not afraid of the great assembly and expound the Dharma for them;

Second, bodhisattvas have faith and understanding in the principles of the Dharma, and thus attain the power of forbearance. They do not give rise to or emerge from anything. Having faith and understanding in the Dharma, they attain the forbearance of non-arising. Having attained the forbearance of the Dharma, they enter into the Dharma of emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness. They are not afraid of the great assembly and expound the Dharma for them;

Third, bodhisattvas contemplate the gate of liberation of the ÅšrÄvaka Vehicle and the faith, understanding, and insight of the Pratyekabuddha Vehicle, and they believe in all entrances and also believe in liberation. Just as they know the necessary medicines for the illnesses of sentient beings, they also know in this way the maturity of the faculties of all sentient beings. Knowing in this way, they teach the Dharma as appropriate. Bodhisattvas are not afraid of the great assembly and teach the Dharma for them.

Fourth, bodhisattvas are free from fear of the great assembly. At that time, they do not have the thought, If someone comes from the east, west, south, or north to challenge me with difficult questions, I will be unable to answer. They are not afraid of being unable to answer, and they do not see any signs of fear. Bodhisattvas are like this. If any sentient beings ask difficult questions, they are all able to answer. In accordance with the questions and difficulties, they answer without fear and are able to cut off all the doubts in the minds of sentient beings. They are not afraid of the great assembly and teach the Dharma for them.
King of Effortlessness!
These are the four kinds of fearlessness of bodhisattvas.
King of Effortlessness!
What are the eighteen uncommon dharmas of bodhisattvas?

Namely, bodhisattvas, without being taught by others, give away wealth and use it for generosity, and moreover, as soon as they are born, they are able to arouse the mind of giving away wealth and using it for generosity.
Moreover, if MÄra, the evil one, were to transform into the body of a buddha and say such words:

This is the first uncommon dharma of bodhisattvas.
King of Effort!

Moreover, bodhisattvas, without being taught by others, in a time when the TathÄgata has not yet appeared and there is no place to receive precepts, aspire to study the correct practice of the prÄtimoká¹£a, and do not abandon this uncommon dharma.

Moreover, bodhisattvas are free from all birth without effort, their physical actions are pure, they are far removed from killing, they bestow fearlessness upon all sentient beings, they do not harm sentient beings with hands, clods, sticks, or knives, they are far removed from knives and sticks, and do not carry them in their hands.

All the devas and humans observe the bodhisattva and have this kind of mind:

This is the tenth uncommon dharma of the bodhisattvas.
Stirred-up King!

This is the twelfth uncommon dharma of the bodhisattvas.

Moreover, the bodhisattva dwells in a good country and a place of wealth and happiness, yet does not know how to contemplate the Buddha. There are devas who have seen the Buddha before who teach him to recollect [the Buddha]. First reprimanding him, they teach him in this way:

Those devas thus instruct and cause them to remember the path to enlightenment, not to transgress or abandon it.

This is the thirteenth uncommon dharma of the bodhisattvas.
Stirred-up King!

Because the bodhisattvas do not retaliate against their evil, but place those evildoers in the true Dharma to make their minds pure.
Although they create evil, by the power of the bodhisattvas they do not enter the evil destinies.
Why is this?
Because that bodhisattva originally has such pure precepts that are not shared by others, and has this kind of mind:

This is the fourteenth bodhisattva precept that is not shared by others.
King of Effort!

Having seen the bodhisattva, they immediately pay homage, respect, and honor him, giving rise to thoughts of reverence and deep faith.

This is the sixteenth uncommon quality of bodhisattvas.

Moreover, wherever a bodhisattva is born, in whatever clan - whether a village, city, or where people gather - there the wholesome qualities of beings increase and unwholesome qualities are eliminated, maturing beings and embracing the true Dharma.

As those beings are embraced by the bodhisattva's wholesome roots, when they die they are reborn in the heavens or among humans.

Moreover, the bodhisattva accords with all the factors of enlightenment, and his superior penetrations are fulfilled, so that all demons are unable to take advantage of him.
Fenzhunwang!

Fenzhunwang!

At that time, Fenzhunwang Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
It is rare!
World-Honored One!

As I understand the Dharma meaning spoken by the Buddha:

If they hear it and accept, uphold, and recite it, those people will then encompass all the Buddha's teachings;
If a person is able to contemplate this Dharma door correctly, then they will have already cultivated all Buddha Dharmas and attained the acceptance of the Dharma in this Dharma door;
If there is someone who is able to practice this Dharma door, then they will have already practiced all Buddha Dharmas.

Moreover, World-Honored One!

From which dharma do you arise?'

Form does not regress, nor does form arise;

In this way, causes and conditions do not come together, there is no retrogression, and no rebirth.
' In this way, the bodhisattva teaches this Dharma to the assembly of bodhisattvas and then subsequently retrogresses.
